physical_appearance:\The map depicts the South-eastern region of the Banda islands. Different colours are used on the different islands
 ranging from pink to turquoise to yellow.  The scale that is being utilized in this map is 1 : 25. There are no latitudes and longitudes on this map
 nor are there any black lines that extend out from the compass that is located on the right of the map from its middle. There is a pictorial representation of mountains and hills drawn on the island of \\Het Land der Popoas\\. \
subject_terms_1:colonial settlements islands (landforms)
subject_terms_2:Colonization East Indies Maps Islands Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie Banda Islands (Indonesia) depictions (visual works)
sgcool_label_text:Francois Valentijn (1666–1727) was a minister
 naturalist and writer who served the Dutch V.O.C. in the East Indies in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. His monumental work Oud en Nieuw Oost-Indien (Old and New East-India)
 published between 1724 and 1726
 offers a comprehensive mapping of the East Indies with a large selection of scale maps and views. This map of the South-eastern Banda islands
 with part of Australia at the lower part of the map
 was published in that work.

metadata.title_text: Kaart van de Zuyd-Ooster Eylanden van Banda (Map of the South-eastern Banda Islands)
metadata.physical_appearance: "The map depicts the South-eastern region of the Banda islands. Different colours are used on the different islands, ranging from pink to turquoise to yellow.  The scale that is being utilized in this map is 1 : 25. There are no latitudes and longitudes on this map, nor are there any black lines that extend out from the compass that is located on the right of the map from its middle. There is a pictorial representation of mountains and hills drawn on the island of ""Het Land der Popoas"". "
metadata.subject_terms_2: Colonization East Indies Maps Islands Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie Banda Islands (Indonesia) depictions (visual works)
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Francois Valentijn (1666–1727) was a minister, naturalist and writer who served the Dutch V.O.C. in the East Indies in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. His monumental work Oud en Nieuw Oost-Indien (Old and New East-India), published between 1724 and 1726, offers a comprehensive mapping of the East Indies with a large selection of scale maps and views. This map of the South-eastern Banda islands, with part of Australia at the lower part of the map, was published in that work.
